conclusion: The problem involves a plank of length L = 0.60 m and mass M = 0.40 kg leaning against a smooth vertical wall. A block of mass m = 0.80 kg is at the lower right of the plank. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the plank is μ = 0.20, and the maximum static friction is equal to the kinetic friction. The goal is to determine the condition on the horizontal force F1 applied to the block to make the plank move upward.

The image shows a plank leaning against a smooth vertical wall. A block is positioned at the lower right of the plank. A horizontal force F1 is applied to the left on the block, and a vertical force F2 is applied upward on the block.

The forces acting on the block are: (1) the horizontal force F1 applied to the left, (2) the vertical force F2 applied upward, (3) the frictional force f between the block and the plank, and (4) the gravitational force mg acting downward.

premise: The block is initially at rest, so its initial velocity is zero. To make the plank move upward, the block must accelerate upward.
conclusion: The net force acting on the block must be upward for the plank to move upward.

premise: The net force is the sum of the forces acting on the block: F1, F2, and the frictional force f.
conclusion: The force F1 must be greater than the frictional force f to cause the block to accelerate.

premise: The frictional force f is given by the equation f = μmg, where μ is the coefficient of kinetic friction, m is the mass of the block, and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
conclusion: The frictional force f can be calculated as f = 0.20 × 0.80 × 10 = 1.6 N.

premise: The sliding friction between the block and the plank is f = μF1. To make the plank move upward, it is required that f > Mg, where M is the mass of the plank and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
conclusion: The condition for the plank to move upward is μF1 > Mg.

premise: The condition μF1 > Mg must be satisfied. Substituting the values μ = 0.20, M = 0.40 kg, and g = 10 m/s² into the inequality gives 0.20F1 > 0.40 × 10.
conclusion: The inequality simplifies to F1 > 20 N.

premise: The inequality F1 > 20 N is derived as the condition for the plank to move upward.
